text.p: Norwegian food-based conglomerate Orkla ASA said on Friday it had agreed to take over the stake held by Swedish auto maker AB Volvo in beverages company Pripps-Ringnes.
Orkla said in a statement it valued Volvo's 55-percent share of the jointly-owned firm at four billion NOK. Orkla said it would take over Pripps-Ringnes with immediate effect.

"Orkla and Volvo have entered into an agreement whereby Orkla will immediately take over Volvo's ownership interest in Pripps-Ringnes, which will thereby become a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Orkla Group," said the statement, which was issued with Orkla's 1996 profits.

Pripps-Ringnes comprises the companies Pripps in Sweden, Ringnes in Norway and the 50-percent owned Baltic Beverages Holding (BBH), which has seven breweries in the Baltic States, Russia and Ukraine. In addition, Pripps-Ringnes owns 20.5 percent of the Finnish brewery Hartwall, the other owner of BBH.

"The parties agree that the bulk of the payment will be made towards the end of 1997," it said. "The agreement is conditional upon the approval of Orkla's corporate assembly. Orkla will not be undertaking an equity issue in connection with the acquisition."

Orkla took over the Volvo food companies Procordia Food and Abba Seafood in 1995. At the same time, Pripps and Ringnes merged to become Pripps-Ringnes, in which Orkla has so far had a 45-percent financial interest.
"Orkla's takeover of the rest of Pripps-Ringnes marks the final chapter in the takeover of all Volvo's food and beverage operations," Orkla said.
"The Nordic countries are the natural home market for Orkla's branded products. Outside the Nordic countries, the strongest growth will mainly be in niche areas or special geographical areas.

"Eastern Europe is one such area where Orkla has been working on several fronts for some time. The full takeover of Pripps-Ringnes confirms Orkla's position in the Nordic region and gives the Group a strong position in Eastern Europe. The takeover therefore strengthens the Group's branded products business," the statement said.
